channel.title: The Moscow Times - News, Business, Culture & Multimedia from Russia
channel.description: The Moscow Times offers everything you need to know about Russia: Breaking news, top stories, business, analysis, opinion, multimedia, upcoming cultural events

item.title: Russian State TV Praises Trump for Avoiding ‘Democracy’ in Inauguration Speech
item.description: Though he welcomed the end of Obama’s presidency as the start of a bright new era, the Kremlin’s “chief propagandist” quickly found himself struggling to find convincing scapegoats for the world’s problems this week.

item.title: Innovative Uzbek Cuisine at Oxus
item.description: Located in a two-story mansion right next to an Armenian church in the Maryina Roshcha neighborhood, Oxus presents an alternative take on Central Asian cuisine, distinctly different from ubiquitous chains like Chaikhona #1.

item.title: Moscow TV Round-Up: Russians in London, Russians and Poles, Russians at War and Much More
item.description: It’s Good Literature, Good Neighbors and Good Riddance Week on Russian TV, as two Russian novelists and a poet get their due; Russian-Polish relations get a going-over; and the trauma of World War II gets put a bit further behind us.

item.title: A Multimedia Voyage into Space at Artplay
item.description: If gazing at swirling star constellations and listening to the sounds of David Bowie’s “Space Oddity” is your idea of an afternoon well spent, a trip to Artplay could be in order. The former factory complex, now a vibrant cultural venue, is hosting the celestially inspired exhibition “Kosmos.Love” through the end of the month.

item.title: Unattainable Utopia: How Alexei Kudrin Plans to Reform Russia's Economy (Op-Ed)
item.description: Putin and his cronies will never give liberals the right to change a country that they feel belongs to them alone.

item.title: Mightier Than the Sword: How Politics Is Tearing Apart PEN Russia
item.description: The expulsion of a prominent writer has split Russia's writer community and brought back ghosts of Soviet censorship.

item.title: Trump’s Fans in Russia Welcome Him to Power, But the Buzz Is Fading
item.description: With Donald Trump’s presidency now a cold, hard reality, it is almost as if Russia's ultra-patriots suddenly recognize how bizarre it is to celebrate a foreign country’s election results.

item.title: Avant-Garde Exhibit Builds a Bridge
item.description: Toward the end of 2016, the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts opened a major exhibit celebrating Georgian avant-garde art from 1900 to the 1930s. This is the first large scale exhibition of Georgian avant-garde artists in Russia.

item.title: They Fought the Law: Russia Edges Closer to Decriminalizing Domestic Violence
item.description: The story of a law protecting victims of familial abuse that only lasted seven months in Russia.

item.title: A Small Victory for Liberals: With Oil Prices Rising, Russia Starts Saving
item.description: Without any reasons for optimism other than a rise in oil prices and a very illusive hope that the West will lift its sanctions, the government reasons that it will probably need that money it has set aside for a rainy day sooner than later.

item.title: Kompromat By Any Other Name
item.description: Since the whole world is talking about kompromat, we might as well talk about it, too.

item.title: Massive CIA Data Dump Reveals Work on UFOs, Secret Tunnels and Soviet Jokes
item.description: The CIA has published 12 million pages of declassified documents, including thousands of intelligence files on the USSR.

item.title: Facebook Temporarily Suspends ‘RT’ Ahead of Trump's Inauguration, and Moscow Is Pissed
item.description: Kremlin-funded news outlet RT was briefly blocked from posting photos or videos via its Facebook page as part of a reported copyright dispute.

item.title: Moscow Restaurants: News & Openings
item.description: from craft beer to khinkali dumplings - our selection of new restaurants

item.title: Spy Games: How The Spectre of Surveillance Impacts Moscow’s Foreigners
item.description: High-profile allegations of Russian surveillance have Moscow’s foreign population asking themselves: am I being watched? Some are. But perceptions often outpace the realities.

item.title: Trump and Putin: More Than a ‘Reset’
item.description: With the official start of the Trump era, Russia’s leadership is celebrating a moral victory over the world’s liberal order and expecting its current values – and interests – to start expanding westward.

item.title: Heavenly Real Estate
item.description: The Kremlin might exchange the iconic cathedral for the Orthodox Church's blessing to bury the remains of Tsarevich Alexei and Grand Duchess Maria, ahead of the Bolshevik Revolution's centennial, later this year.

item.title: From Russia With Octopussy
item.description: Moscow may have been serious when it revealed America's cross-dressing spies, but there has been plenty of laughter online, where Internet users are sharing photos of absurdly dressed people, claiming shocking discoveries.

item.title: Ruski: New Russian Cuisine Above the Clouds
item.description: Ruski is a new restaurant on the 85th floor of OKO, the highest skyscraper in the Moskva City neighborhood. Part of the 354 Exclusive Height project created by two restaurant empires — Chaikhona #1 and GINZA — and several independent restaurateurs, Ruski combines carefully researched traditional Russian dishes with contemporary Russian cuisine.

item.title: Spies in Wigs
item.description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov used his annual press conference to moan about Western liberal values, cross-dressing U.S. spies, and Washington's failures fighting terrorism.

item.title: Russian State Bank Loaned $11.6 Bln to Start Rosneft Privatization Deal
item.description: Kremlin-owned Russian bank VTB provided a loan needed to kick-started the privatization of Russian energy giant Rosneft, the RBC news outlet has revealed.

item.title: Eastern Europe: Between Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin
item.description: The Kremlin views all former Warsaw Pact countries as Russia’s zone of influence within Europe – all the more so when the right populist leader comes to power.

item.title: UK and Russia after Trump and Brexit: What’s Next?
item.description: Only a change in government policy by Russia will provoke a change in Britain’s policy toward Russia. But there's no sign that it's happening.

item.title: So Long, Joe
item.description: Biden's last trip to Ukraine had less to do with resolving urgent business than convincing the Trump administration that Ukraine should remain a priority for U.S. foreign policy.

item.title: Russian State Television Flips President Obama a Farewell Bird
item.description: Dmitry Kiselyov's TV show often has somber overtones, but this Sunday's episode was quite jubilant: it’s the last time he goes on the air with Obama still in the White House.

item.title: Russian Historical Revisionism Goes to the Movies
item.description: Earning a record-breaking billion rubles in nine days, the historical Russian film “Viking” is confidently marching to the number one spot at the box office. It may even displace the highest-grossing Russian film ever — Fyodor Bondarchuk’s WWII action film, “Stalingrad.” The Nordic-themed hit was produced by Konstantin Ernst, director general of Russia’s Channel One, and directed by Andrei Kravchuk, known for his biopics on civil war-era White Russian leader Alexander Kolchak, and the Soviet cult singer-songwriter, Vladimir Vysotsky.

item.title: Activist Pavlensky Flees Russia Seeking Political Asylum Amid Rape Allegations
item.description: Russian activist Pyotr Pavlensky is applying for political asylum in France, the Hromadske news outlet reported Monday.

item.title: Russia vs. The Global Order: What Will Trump's Divided Administration Do About It?
item.description: If Moscow plays its cards right and does not get too pushy, it could get Trump do Russia's work in terms of disrupting US alliances and weakening US power.

item.title: Russia Hopes to End Agricultural Counter Sanctions by 2017
item.description: Which is more important to the Russian authorities: a winning foreign policy or the success of their import substitution program? “The time has come to understand that sanctions or counter sanctions will soon end,” said First Deputy Prime Minister Igor Shuvalov, speaking at the Gaidar Forum in Moscow. “In any case, in my work, and that of the Agriculture Minister and Economics Minister, we probably need to understand that counter sanctions will be repealed.”

item.title: Moscow TV Round-Up: High-Rises, High-Flyers, Death Rays and a Pole Pretending to be an American
item.description: It’s Everything But the Kitchen Sink Week on Moscow TV, as the small screen puts on an exotic smorgasbord indeed: you get everything from a Pole playing an American to a rare screening of a classic of early Russian propaganda – or is it early Russian fake propaganda?

item.title: Damned Either Way
item.description: You might think officials in Kiev have no bone to pick with anyone in Russia’s anti-Kremlin opposition, but you’d be wrong.

item.title: The Treasure Guardian: Keeping the Kremlin Jewels Safe
item.description: The woman entrusted with preserving Tsarist Russia’s masterpieces enjoys a famous name and the support of the President. But that doesn’t make her job easy.

item.title: Kadyrov's Hollywood
item.description: Under the close watch of the republic’s strongman leader, Chechen movie pioneers are producing the world’s most unexpected cinema.

item.title: Have a Very Jazzy Weekend
item.description: For lovers of jazz who maxed out their credit cards over the holiday, Moscow's jazz clubs come to the rescue. The newly opened Jam Club is offering some serious discounts. And the Essé Jazz Club has some seriously great events.

item.title: Seven Ideas to Help You Get Back into Shape
item.description: Russia’s weeklong New Year’s holiday is finally over. Whether you spent it in Moscow winding your way from one house party to another in the time-honored Russian tradition, or you have just come back from a seaside vacation in the sub-tropics, you need to get back into your regular working routine. Thankfully, Moscow has plenty of activities to help wake you from that post-vacation lethargy and get in shape for the new year. Here is where you’ll find us as we do our annual post-holiday detox.

item.title: Moscow on Stage: The Celebration Goes On
item.description: If you’re still in a bit of a holiday mood, here are two performances you might want to catch over the next week. Pleasure – guaranteed.

item.title: The Voyage Home: What Russia's Withdrawal Means for Syria
item.description: Even with its naval battlegroup headed for home, Russia is not withdrawing from Syria. It is merely changing posture.

item.title: "I'm Shocked, Just Shocked!" in Three Russian Letters
item.description: Today we’re going to master how to blurt out surprise in Russian. First up: Опа! — almost always printed with an exclamation mark.

item.title: Russian Troops Being Briefed for Deployment in Syria — Reports
item.description: Russian army personal are being briefed for deployment in Syria, according to military brochures obtained by Russia's Novaya Gazeta newspaper.

item.title: Trump’s Unflappable Texan Is in for a World of Chaos (Op-ed)
item.description: The new job will require Rex Tillerson to leave the traditional corporate comfort zone of rational calculations and well-established facts.

item.title: Russian TV Channel Dozhd Suspended in Ukraine
item.description: Independent Russian television channel Dozhd has been suspended in Ukraine after repeatedly showing Crimea as part of Russia.

item.title: Russia Is No Nirvana: How Yogis Are Becoming a Persecuted Minority
item.description: An innocuous blend of gymnastics and Eastern philosophy increasingly popular with Russians has found itself the latest target of a series of repressive laws aimed at squeezing out dissent.

item.title: Muchnik's Picks: Masha i Medvedi, Meydeleh and More Music in Moscow on the Weekend
item.description: The longest weekend of the year is over, but the city of Moscow is still half-asleep. The roads are semi-empty and everyone is preparing to celebrate another holiday – the quirky Old New Year's Eve. So it's no wonder that most gigs this weekend are played by popular Russian bands.

item.title: You Thought This Was Rock Bottom, America, But the Russians Are Knocking From Below
item.description: Russian Twitter users who tuned in to watch Trump’s meeting with the press weren’t partying or seething — for the most part, they were laughing.

item.title: Hacked Off: The Cyber Scandal Will Undermine Trump's Russian Reset
item.description: Both the president-elect and the Kremlin want the hacking issue to die. It won't.

item.title: Golden Skepticism
item.description: In what has become a growing trend, the dossier has provoked reactions from commentators typically critical of Moscow that largely converge with responses from pro-Kremlin pundits.

item.title: Bill Decriminalizing Domestic Violence Passes First Reading in Russian Parliament
item.description: A bill decriminalizing domestic violence has passed its first reading in Russia's State Duma. Some 368 lawmakers voted in favor of the law, with just one deputy voting against the plans.

item.title: No Beacon On the Hill: Trump's Win in the Mirror of the Soviet Collapse
item.description: Russia’s rulers are of course convinced that smart intelligence work did play a major role in the collapse of the Soviet Union. And, of course, thoughts of a payback did enter their minds more than once.

item.title: Trump Backed by Kremlin for 'Years,' Claims Unverified Dossier
item.description: An unverified dossier accusing Russia of gathering sexually explicit material to blackmail U.S. President-elect Donald Trump has been published online by American news site Buzzfeed.

item.title: Don’t Say It
item.description: They say “sex sells,” but don't go peddling it near dinner tables in Russia, where families in an ostensibly conservative society say the subject is too taboo to discuss at home.
